timeline.bodyText: I don't think @NonNullByDefault should be used here. It's probably to get rid of the warning related to the Set? I think you should just remove the annotation. Same for method below.
timeline.author: Hilbrand

replies.bodyText: I don't remember anymore, probably done for some reason a while ago. But Eclipse does not give warnings anymore when removing, so removed.
replies.author: mherwege

timeline.author: Hilbrand

replies.bodyText: You also might want to add a bit of javadoc either to the interface or method about what this interface/method does.

These if statements can be a switch.

                        if (("container".equals(qName) || "item".equals(qName))) {
          
          
            
                        switch (qName) {
          
          
            
                        case "container":

                        ...
timeline.author: Hilbrand
Hilbrand
Hilbrand
Hilbrand
Hilbrand

timeline.bodyText: static fields should be above other fields.
timeline.author: Hilbrand

timeline.bodyText:
You can put the id's and refId in a set, which is faster. With a list it needs to iterate over all elements. Create the set before the forEach:
final Set<String> idSet = list.stream().map(UpnpEntry::getId).collect(Collectors.toSet());

And then do !idSet.contains(refId) here.
The refIdList can used as is, only be replaced by a Set.
timeline.author: Hilbrand
Hilbrand
Hilbrand

timeline.bodyText: Prefer to iterate over entrySet because keySet makes a copy of the values to a new list.
timeline.author: Hilbrand

timeline.bodyText: This can probably just be a ArrayList or just pass values() (in which case filterEntries should accept a Collection?
timeline.author: Hilbrand
Hilbrand

timeline.bodyText: Pattern can be made a field.
timeline.author: Hilbrand
Hilbrand

timeline.bodyText:
Not sure why this is a LinkedList. No specific linked list functionality is used. So it probably can just be a ArrayList.
The list is used to walk over this list, and the index is kept for that. This can also be achived by using a listIterator() (It's a method on for example ArrayList or LinkedList). And then you can simply use next() and previous() and it will maintain the position. (Also you can use hasNext to see if you're at the end of the list).
timeline.author: Hilbrand

replies.bodyText: This one was a challenge. It looked simple at first, but a ListIterator does not keep a position. The result of next() and previous() depends on the previous command. But I was down a path implementing it, and unfortunately, did not put the rest in a separate commit, so couldn't easily go back. Here is the Stackflow article I used as a basis for my solution.
replies.author: mherwege

timeline.author: Hilbrand
Hilbrand
Hilbrand
Hilbrand

timeline.bodyText: The config variables should be stored in a variable in the initialize() method. You can define a class with the variables and use getConfigAs.
timeline.author: Hilbrand

timeline.bodyText:
These should probably not be logged to error as it indicates a problem with the data, not specifically with the binding. Error logging in openHAB is intended for severe errors.
When the exception would be thrown, dioes it still make sense to call invokeAction? otherwise the call (and map) should be inside the try-catch.
timeline.author: Hilbrand

timeline.bodyText: Same comment about error here as above.
timeline.author: Hilbrand

timeline.message:
Further adjustments after code review.

Signed-off-by: Mark Herwege <mark.herwege@telenet.be>

timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: Apache Commons won't be available in OH3 by default. @cweitkamp Is there a replacement function for (un)escaping XML?
timeline.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText:
I am afraid there is not (see #7722 (comment)).
TL;DR I am not aware of a Java 8 equivalent. My proposal is to add a util class in OHC.
replies.author: cweitkamp

replies.bodyText: @fwolter I copied this from the Sonos binding. So can I leave it for now? Multiple bindings will have to be adjusted the same way later I assume.
replies.author: mherwege

replies.bodyText: I see no other way at the moment. Please add a dependency for Apache Commons to your pom.xml and the NOTICE file to be able to compile it with OH3, too.
replies.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText: No. It's still available and will be replaced with openHAB 3 with something provided by core. For now it's ok to use. We should not add depdencirs like this.
replies.author: Hilbrand

timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: When the configuration changed, this class will be re-used. To reload the configuration, getConfigAs() should be called in initialize().
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                    return;
timeline.author: fwolter
fwolter

timeline.bodyText: Are you aware that volatile doesn't make it synchronized? If I see correctly, onValueReceived() can be invoked concurrently, so these should be synchronized.
timeline.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText:
I am aware of this. But I am not good at it at all and always struggle to know where and how to use synchronization. I had not run into issues so far, so ignored it. I probably should not have.
onValueReceived could indeed, in theory, be called concurrently. However, each call would come from a media server and/or renderer device in sequence, so in practice, I have not seen issues so far.
How could I best proceed?
replies.author: mherwege
fwolter
mherwege

replies.bodyText: Your arguments are correct. Synchronization is not needed, then, and volatile is ok.
replies.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: Can these be removed?
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: See above
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: getChannel() can return null. Same for below.
timeline.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText: @fwolter These channels are statically defined in the thing-types.xml file. According to the method declaration, they would only return null if no channel with the ID exists. Can there be a situation where the statically defined channel does not exist yet at this point in the code? Wouldn't that be an error in OH core?
replies.author: mherwege

replies.bodyText: It will return null if one of these Channels would be renamed or removed in further versions and the user wants to continue using his Things.
replies.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText: OK. I changed it. But wouldn't the same argument apply when calling updateState(String, String) where the first argument is the channel ID string? I don't do a check in that case either.
replies.author: mherwege

replies.bodyText: Calling updateState(String, String) on a non-existent ChannelUID is safe. See org.eclipse.smarthome.core.thing.internal.CommunicationManager:483.
replies.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: It's bad practice to catch unchecked exceptions. You could use ifPresent() to execute the code in a lambda or isPresent() to check via an if.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: Do you mean break?
timeline.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText: Yes. But I now solved it differently with a CompletableFuture.
replies.author: mherwege
